headline: Wisconsin Senate race tightens as rivals close in on Barnes
sentences: The poll is the latest sign that the battleground primary has become a close race between Barnes, a progressive backed by Sen. Elizabeth Warren and the Working Families Party, and Lasry, a more center-left candidate who has won the endorsement of local labor unions.

Thirty-four percent of likely Democratic voters support Barnes, while 31 percent are for Lasry, 18 percent back state Treasurer Sarah Godlewski, and 5 percent are behind Outagamie County Executive Tom Nelson, a survey commissioned by Lasry's campaign found.

Maddy McDaniel, a spokesperson for Barnes said, Not even $8 million of the Lasry fortune can take away Mandela's lead because voters know Mandela was born and raised in Wisconsin's middle class and has spent the last decade fighting for working families.

Jill Normington, a partner at the firm Normington Petts, which conducted the poll, said Lasry has gained ground in the survey because his record of getting things done, about using his progressive values in the private sector is resonating with voters.
He first started going on air last week with a television commercial that highlights his middle-class roots  and takes a dig at the other millionaires running for Senate.
She pounced on the news of the leaked Roe v. Wade draft opinion, holding an impromptu press conference outside of the Supreme Court and cutting a TV ad there.
Self-funders usually get a big bump when they're on air unopposed but now that we're communicating, we fully expect to maintain and grow our lead.

| Scott Olson/Getty Images
By Holly Otterbein
 05/27/2022 04:30 AM EDT
Milwaukee Bucks executive Alex Lasry is closing in on Lt. Gov.
Mandela Barnes speaks at a rally for Wisconsin Democrats at North Division High School on October 26, 2018 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.
Barnes, whose position as a statewide official helped him build name recognition, began the primary as the clear frontrunner.
The margin of error for the poll, which was conducted from May 18 to 22, was plus or minus 3.7 percentage points.
Lasry, who has loaned millions out of his own pocket to his campaign, began airing TV ads in October 2021.
Another survey by Marquette University Law School in April showed Barnes and Lasry in a statistical tie.
The winner of the Democratic Senate race will face Republican Sen. Ron Johnson in the fall.
Mandela Barnes in Wisconsin's Senate Democratic primary, according to a new internal poll.
Godlewski also saw a bump in the Lasry campaign's poll from 7 percent in February.
Twelve percent of voters in Lasry's internal survey were undecided.
He is on leave from his job with the NBA team.
Godlewski has also helped finance her own bid.
Wisconsin's primary will be held Aug. 9.
